artists.name: La Monte Young
artists.description: The Dream Syndicate and eternal drones. One of the first to bring sustained tones into modern composition.

artists.name: Terry Riley
artists.description: In C (1964) and tape delay experiments; huge influence on rock and electronic music.

artists.name: Steve Reich
artists.description: Phasing works like It’s Gonna Rain, turning tape loops into structural music.

artists.name: Philip Glass
artists.description: Repetition and additive structures, setting up 1970s minimalist soundscapes.

artists.name: Pauline Oliveros
artists.description: Deep Listening pioneer, accordionist, feminist composer, creating meditative experimental works.

artists.name: Ornette Coleman
artists.description: Free Jazz (1961) opened the floodgates.

artists.name: John Coltrane
artists.description: Spiritual explorations like Ascension pushed jazz into transcendence.

artists.name: Sun Ra & His Arkestra
artists.description: Myth-science Afrofuturism, combining big band, electronics, and outer space.

artists.name: AACM (Chicago)
artists.description: Founded in 1965, nurturing Anthony Braxton, Art Ensemble of Chicago — radical improvisation plus theatricality.

artists.name: The Velvet Underground
artists.description: Andy Warhol’s Factory house band. Noise, drones, taboo subjects — decades ahead of punk and art-rock.

artists.name: The Mothers of Invention (Frank Zappa)
artists.description: Satire, modern composition techniques, and guitar chaos.

artists.name: Silver Apples
artists.description: One of the first rock/electronic hybrids, centered on oscillators.

artists.name: The Fugs
artists.description: Beat poets + raw folk rock = counterculture satire.

artists.name: The Beatles (UK)
artists.description: Revolver and Sgt. Pepper’s defined psychedelic studio wizardry.

artists.name: The Beach Boys (US)
artists.description: Brian Wilson’s Pet Sounds changed arrangements forever.

artists.name: Pink Floyd (UK)
artists.description: Syd Barrett-era chaos at UFO Club, blending freeform improvisation with light shows.

artists.name: Jefferson Airplane / Grateful Dead (US)
artists.description: San Francisco’s Haight-Ashbury scene, psychedelic jams for the counterculture.

artists.name: BBC Radiophonic Workshop (UK)
artists.description: Delia Derbyshire’s Doctor Who theme = one of the most important moments in electronic music.

artists.name: Morton Subotnick (US)
artists.description: Silver Apples of the Moon (1967), first commissioned electronic LP.

artists.name: Wendy Carlos (US)
artists.description: Switched-On Bach popularized the Moog synthesizer in 1968.

artists.name: Fluxus & Happenings (US)
artists.description: Yoko Ono, George Maciunas, John Cage influencing experimental rock with performance art.

artists.name: Cornelius Cardew (UK)
artists.description: Scratch Orchestra, blending political radicalism with experimental scoring.

artists.name: AMM (UK)
artists.description: Improvised noise group, laying foundations for industrial and free improvisation scenes.

artists.name: Bob Dylan (US)
artists.description: From protest folk to surreal rock poetry.

artists.name: Joan Baez / Phil Ochs (US)
artists.description: Politically charged protest folk.

artists.name: Fairport Convention (UK)
artists.description: Merging traditional British folk with rock.
